[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Patel, I need to escalate a concern about Mr. Thomas Nguyen, 74 years old, currently in bed 5 on the urology ward. He’s been deteriorating clinically — I’m not exactly sure what’s triggering it, but I think he needs a medical review soon, possibly urgently.
[DOCTOR]: Okay, what’s going on?
[NURSE]: He was admitted yesterday with acute urinary retention and a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia. A catheter was inserted last night, but over the last few hours he seems to have become more lethargic, tachycardic, and hypotensive. His urine output’s dropped quite a bit — not sure if the catheter’s blocked or if he’s just shutting down.
[DOCTOR]: What are his current vitals?
[NURSE]: BP’s sitting around 88/54, HR about 112, RR 22, SpO₂ 96% on room air, temp 37.9°C. He’s only passed about 40 mL in the last three hours, give or take. His Q‑ADDS is around 7, though I’ll double‑check — it might be 8 depending on the scoring for output.
[DOCTOR]: Any pain or other symptoms?
[NURSE]: He’s got some lower abdominal discomfort — says it’s “tight” more than painful — and a low‑grade fever. He’s a bit confused, which the team on shift earlier didn’t mention, so that’s new. No vomiting that I’ve seen, but he’s refusing fluids and looks a little clammy.
[DOCTOR]: Any recent bloods?
[NURSE]: Yes, this morning’s labs: white cell 14.6, CRP 98, creatinine 168 from 102 yesterday, eGFR down to 44 — sorry, I think it’s 44, not 4, but I can confirm. Looks like he might be heading into an acute kidney injury, possibly secondary to infection, obstruction, or both. Micro hasn’t come back yet, but urine looked cloudy.
[DOCTOR]: Okay, thanks. I’ll come and review him now — give me about ten minutes. We may need imaging and probably to escalate to the surgical team if obstruction’s worsening. I’ll decide once I’ve seen him.
[NURSE]: Alright, I’ll keep an eye on him for now and prepare in case you want to transfer or escalate further.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Lee, I need you to review Ms. Margaret Doyle in bed 7. She’s an 82-year-old patient who had an unwitnessed fall in her room about 45 minutes ago. She hit her head on the bedside cabinet and has a visible occipital hematoma.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. What’s her current condition?
[NURSE]: She’s alert but drowsy. Her GCS is 14—she opens eyes to voice, is confused, and obeys commands. She’s complaining of a headache and mild nausea. No vomiting so far.
[DOCTOR]: Any neuro obs or vitals?
[NURSE]: Yes, we’ve started ½-hourly neuro obs. Her latest set: GCS: 14 ,BP: 132/78, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 18, Temp: 36.8°C, SpO?: 97% on room air, Q-ADDS score: 4 (GCS + nausea + age)
[DOCTOR]: Any bloods done?
[NURSE]: Yes, we drew bloods post-fall. FBC shows: Hb: 122, WCC: 8.6, Platelets: 210, INR: 1.1 Creatinine: 75, She’s not on anticoagulants.
[DOCTOR]: Any other injuries?
[NURSE]: No other obvious trauma. No limb pain or deformity. She mobilised with assistance post-fall but was unsteady.
[DOCTOR]: Okay. We’ll need a CT head to rule out intracranial bleeding. Can you keep neuro obs going and notify me of any GCS drop or vomiting?
[NURSE]: I’ll book the CT and continue neuro obs. I’ll escalate if her Q-ADDS increases or if she becomes more confused

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Nguyen, I need you to review Ms. Lara Bennett in bed 5. She’s a 56-year-old patient with a known history of epilepsy. She had a tonic-clonic seizure about 20 minutes ago on the ward. It lasted approximately 90 seconds and she’s now post-ictal—drowsy but rousable.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. Is she stable now?
[NURSE]:Yes, she’s breathing spontaneously and maintaining her airway. No signs of trauma or tongue injury. She’s currently on 4-hourly neuro obs. Her latest vitals are:BP: 138/84, HR: 92 bpm, RR: 16, Temp: 36.9°C, SpO?: 98% on room air, GCS: 13,Q-ADDS score: 4 (GCS + seizure)
[DOCTOR]: Any IV access?
[NURSE]: Yes, she has a patent IV cannula in her left forearm. No IV fluids running currently—she’s tolerating oral intake. No signs of dehydration.
[DOCTOR]: Any allergies?
[NURSE]: Yes, she has a documented allergy to phenytoin—rash and dizziness previously.
[DOCTOR]: Is she catheterised?
[NURSE]: Yes, she has an indwelling catheter (IDC) in place for monitoring. Output has been normal—clear urine, ~300 mL over the last 4 hours.
[DOCTOR]: Any recent bloods?
[NURSE]: Yes, FBC and electrolytes were taken this morning: Hb: 128, WCC: 7.4, Platelets: 240, Na: 136, K: 4.2, Creatinine: 76, No major abnormalities.
[DOCTOR]: Has the family been informed?
[NURSE]: Yes, I’ve spoken to her daughter. She’s on her way in and aware of the situation. I’ve reassured her that Lara is stable but still recovering.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. Let’s continue neuro obs, monitor for any further seizures, and review her antiepileptic regimen. If she has another seizure or her GCS drops, please escalate immediately.
[NURSE]: I’ll keep monitoring and update you if anything changes.

[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Patel, thanks for coming. I’d like you to review Ms. Evelyn Grant in bed 9. She’s a 68-year-old patient admitted with a urinary tract infection. She’s deteriorated over the last few hours.
[DOCTOR]: What’s happening?
[NURSE]: She’s has become increasingly tachycardic and febrile. Her Q-ADDS score is 6, which triggered the escalation. She’s also reporting increased confusion compared to her baseline.
[DOCTOR]: Okay, can you give me her latest observations?
[NURSE]: Her BP: 98/62, HR: 112 bpm, RR: 22, Temp: 38.6°C, SpO?: 95% on room air, Conscious state: Alert but confused, Q-ADDS score: 6 (HR + Temp + RR + confusion).
[DOCTOR]:Has she had any recent bloods or urine cultures?
[NURSE]: Yes, bloods were taken this morning. WCC is 14.2, CRP is 98. Creatinine is slightly up at 102. Urine sample sent, awaiting results.
[DOCTOR]: Any IV access?
[NURSE]: No, she doesn’t currently have a cannula. We’ll need to insert one.
[DOCTOR]: Okay. What’s her allergy status?
[NURSE]: She has a documented penicillin allergy—rash and swelling reported previously.
[DOCTOR]: What’s her current medication chart?
[NURSE]: She’s on: Paracetamol 1g QID, IV fluids: Normal saline at 100 mL/hr, no antibiotics started yet due to allergy—awaiting review.
[DOCTOR]: Alright. I’ll assess her now and likely start IV ceftriaxone and IV gentamicin, given the allergy. We’ll also need to insert a cannula and consider transfer to the acute medical unit if her condition worsens.
[NURSE]: I’ll prepare for the cannula and notify the AMU team if needed.
[DOCTOR]: Let me know if her Q-ADDS score increases or if she becomes more confused.

[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Elaine Morris in bed 6. She’s an 84-year-old patient with reduced mobility following a recent pneumonia admission. She has a stage 2 pressure injury on her right hip.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s the current condition of the wound?
[Outgoing Nurse]: It’s a shallow ulcer with partial thickness skin loss. The wound bed is moist but clean, with no signs of infection. There’s mild erythema around the edges. The wound care nurse reviewed it this morning and recommended continuing with Allevyn Gentle Border dressing.
[Incoming Nurse]: How often does it need changing?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Every 3 days unless soiled or lifting. The next dressing change is due on Friday. We’re documenting progress in the wound chart and taking weekly photos for review.
[Incoming Nurse]: What’s her Waterlow score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Waterlow score is 18, so she’s at high risk. She’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and we’re repositioning her every 2 hours.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any other relevant care?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes:  she has No IV access currently, her Oral intake is adequate, there’s No IDC, but she is continent of urine and bowels, Pain score is 1/10 at rest, no analgesia required, Skin integrity checks are ongoing, no other areas of concern
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue the pressure care, monitor the wound, and follow the dressing schedule.

[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. James Nolan in bed 4. He’s a 67-year-old patient admitted overnight with a suspected small bowel obstruction. He’s been reviewed by the surgical team and is currently awaiting theatre—likely this afternoon.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What are his current symptoms?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s had abdominal distension, nausea, and vomiting since yesterday. No bowel movements for 48 hours. He’s nil by mouth and has an NG tube on free drainage, which has drained about 400 mL of bilious fluid since insertion.
[Incoming Nurse]: What’s his current status?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Vitals are stable: BP: 128/76, HR: 88 bpm, RR: 18, Temp: 37.2°C, SpO?: 97% on room air, Q-ADDS score: 3 (based on nausea, pain, and reduced output)
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in his right forearm—patent. He’s on IV Normal Saline at 125 mL/hr. Electrolytes are being monitored—latest bloods show mild hypokalaemia (K+ 3.2), so we’ve added potassium to his fluids.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any medications?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s charted for: IV Metoclopramide 10 mg TDS, IV Paracetamol 1g QID, PRN Morphine 2.5–5 mg SC for pain, Nil oral meds due to NBM status
[Incoming Nurse]: Any pressure care or hygiene needs?
[Outgoing Nurse]: He’s been in bed most of the shift. We’ve started 2-hourly repositioning and he’s on a pressure-relieving mattress. No current pressure injuries. He’ll need a full wash this morning and assistance with hygiene.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue monitoring and prep him for theatre.

example.text:
[ED Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Luke Harris, a 42-year-old male who presented to ED earlier today following a deliberate overdose. He reportedly ingested approximately 50 Panadol tablets, 20 Serepax, and a bottle of whisky after a fight with his partner.
[Drug & Alcohol Nurse]: Thanks. What’s his current condition?
[ED Nurse]: He’s currently drowsy but rousable, with slurred speech, intermittent agitation, and low oxygen saturations—around 92% on 2 L nasal prongs. GCS is 13. He’s under close observation and has IV access in place. Bloods have been taken for paracetamol levels, LFTs, and coagulation profile. We’re awaiting results to determine if NAC is required.
[Drug & Alcohol Nurse]: Any known substance use history?
[ED Nurse]: He’s a daily smoker and reports heavy alcohol use, especially during periods of stress. No documented history of drug use, but this is his first known overdose. He’s not currently linked in with any mental health or addiction services.
[Drug & Alcohol Nurse]: Any social concerns?
[ED Nurse]: Yes, he lives with his partner, and the overdose occurred following a verbal altercation. He’s currently not safe to discharge and will need a mental health review once medically stable. No children at home, but he’s expressed feelings of hopelessness and anger.
[Drug & Alcohol Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll assess him once he’s more alert and begin planning for support post-discharge, including possible referral to AOD services and counselling.
[ED Nurse]: Perfect. Let me know if you need anything from the medical team or if you’d like to join the MDT review later today.

[NURSE 1]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. David Lee, 64 years old. He’s on the ward post-lobectomy and currently has a left-sided ICC in situ. It’s due to come out today.
[NURSE 2]: Okay, thanks. What’s the current status of the ICC?
[NURSE 1]: ICC has been on free drainage. Output over the last 24 hours is minimal — around 20 mL serous fluid. No air leak noted. Chest X-ray this morning shows good lung expansion. Surgical team reviewed and gave the okay for removal.
[NURSE 2]: Got it. Any pain or discomfort?
[NURSE 1]: He’s had some mild discomfort around the insertion site, but it’s well managed with regular paracetamol. No signs of infection — site is clean and dry.
[NURSE 2]: Any IV access?
[NURSE 1]: Yes, 20G cannula in the right forearm — patent and due for review tomorrow. He’s currently on oral meds only.
[NURSE 2]: I’ll check the med chart. Anything due?
[NURSE 1]: No meds due right now. He’s on regular analgesia and a stool softener. No known allergies.
[NURSE 2]: Any behavioural or cognitive concerns?
[NURSE 1]: No concerns. He’s alert, oriented, and understands the plan. He’s a bit anxious about the ICC removal, so just reassure him and let him know we’ll use local anaesthetic.
[NURSE 2]: Will do. I’ll prep the trolley and notify the team once it’s out.

example.text:
[Outgoing Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Dorothy Lane in bed 5. She’s an 83-year-old patient admitted with a left neck of femur fracture following a fall at home. She’s post-op day 1 following internal fixation. She’s currently confused, intermittently orientated, and requires full assistance with care.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. What’s her current Q-ADDS score?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Her Q-ADDS score is 5—due to confusion, elevated respiratory rate, and low urine output. Latest observations: BP: 118/72, HR: 96 bpm, RR: 22, Temp: 36.9°C, SpO?: 95% on room air, she’s Alert but confused.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any pressure area concerns?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, she has a chronic venous leg ulcer on her right lower leg. It’s being dressed with Iodosorb and a foam dressing, reviewed by wound care yesterday. No sacral or heel breakdown noted. She’s on a pressure-relieving mattress and being repositioned every 2 hours.
[Incoming Nurse]: Is she continent?
[Outgoing Nurse]: No, she’s incontinent of urine and has an IDC in place—draining clear urine, ~400 mL over the last 6 hours. She’s also on a bowel chart—no bowel movement today, last opened bowels yesterday.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any vascular obs?
[Outgoing Nurse]: Yes, we’re doing neurovascular obs on the affected limb: Sensation: Intact, Movement: Limited due to pain, Cap refill: less than 2 seconds, Pedal pulses: Present, Skin temp: Warm.
[Incoming Nurse]: Any IV access or medications?
[Outgoing Nurse]: She has a 20G cannula in her right forearm, patent.
Medications include: IV Cefazolin 1g TDS, Paracetamol 1g QID, PRN Endone 2.5–5 mg Enoxaparin 40 mg SC daily, No known drug allergies.
[Incoming Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue pressure care, monitor her Q-ADDS, and update wound and fluid charts.

example.text:
NURSE: Dr. Lee, Mr. Matthews arrested about 40 minutes ago. We initiated CPR immediately and followed the ALS protocol. He was in asystole throughout. Despite full resuscitation efforts, we were unable to regain a pulse. Time of death was recorded at 11:42 AM.
DOCTOR: Thanks for the update. Were the family contacted?
NURSE: Yes, his wife and daughter are here now. They’re in the quiet room. I’ve let them know there was a serious deterioration, but they don’t know he’s passed yet.
DOCTOR: Alright. Let’s speak with them together. I’ll lead the conversation, and you can support with any nursing or practical details.

example.text:
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m the incoming nurse for bed 6, my name is Cath. Can I get handover now?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Sure. This is bed 6, Sarah Thompson, 24 years old. She was admitted last night under Dr. Malik following a mental health assessment in ED. She’s presenting with severe depressive symptoms and suicidal ideation.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Her symptoms have worsened since the death of her mother from breast cancer about six weeks ago. She’s been socially withdrawn, tearful, and expressing feelings of hopelessness. She disclosed thoughts of ending her life but no current plan or attempt.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any dependents?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she has a 3-year-old daughter who is currently staying with extended family. She’s expressed guilt and distress about not being able to care for her child.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any substance use?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s a daily smoker, no other substances reported. No alcohol or drug use disclosed.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any medical history?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No chronic physical health conditions. No previous psychiatric admissions, but she has a history of low mood and anxiety since adolescence. No known allergies.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How has she been overnight?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Settled but emotionally fragile. She’s been quiet, cooperative with care, but tearful during interactions. No behavioural incidents. She’s on 15-minute observations due to suicide risk.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any medications charted?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]:
She’s started on: Sertraline 50 mg daily, Temazepam 10 mg PRN for sleep, Paracetamol PRN, No antipsychotics or mood stabilisers at this stage. She has no side effects to Sertraline, and her sleep has been good, and she is not sedated.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any referrals?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she’s been referred to the psychologist and social worker for grief counselling and parenting support. Child Safety has been notified due to her current mental state and care arrangements.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll continue close monitoring and follow up with the allied health team.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything escalates. She’s currently resting in her room.

[PATIENT]: Olivia Taylor.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Olivia Taylor in Bed 7, Room 15, aged 38, under Dr. Chen, Emergency Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Taylor presented to ED last night following an assault at home by her intoxicated husband. She has bruising to her left eye and forearm, and a minor laceration to her scalp, which has been cleaned and dressed. CT head was clear. Vitals stable overnight. She’s alert and oriented.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Taylor disclosed that her children are currently at school and she is concerned for their safety. She has not returned home and is unsure of her next steps.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Ms. Taylor, how are you feeling this morning? Any pain or dizziness?
[PATIENT]: Just sore and tired. I’m worried about my kids.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Understandably. Pain score was 5/10 earlier. She’s had oral analgesia and is tolerating fluids. No nausea or vomiting. A social worker was contacted and will be attending shortly to support safety planning and discuss options.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Hi Olivia, I’m Sarah, one of the hospital social workers. I understand you’ve had a very difficult night. I’m here to support you. Would it be okay if we talked for a few minutes?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s okay.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thank you. First, I want to check—are you feeling safe right now? Is your husband aware you’re here?
[PATIENT]: No, he was drunk and passed out when I left. I don’t think he knows.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Okay. We can help ensure your safety while you're here and support you with options for accommodation, legal advice, and child protection if needed. Would you like us to contact someone on your behalf—family, a friend, or a support service?
[PATIENT]: Maybe my sister. She’s in Brisbane.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Absolutely. I’ll help you with that. We’ll also work with the team to make sure your children are safe and supported. You're not alone in this.

[PATIENT]: Rachel Bennett.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thank you. This is Ms. Rachel Bennett in Bed 2, Room 9, aged 52, under Dr. Wallace, Oncology Consultant.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Ms. Bennett is currently receiving cycle 3 of chemotherapy for breast cancer. She’s had mild nausea overnight, managed with antiemetics. Her vitals are stable, and she’s tolerating oral fluids. Bloods were taken this morning for routine monitoring.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s expressed feeling emotionally overwhelmed and worried about managing work and home responsibilities during treatment. A social worker referral was made, and they’re scheduled to visit later this morning.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Hi Rachel, I’m Priya, one of the hospital social workers. I understand you’re going through a lot right now, and I’m here to support you. Is it okay if we talk for a few minutes?
[PATIENT]: Yes, please. I’ve been struggling a bit.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thank you. I know chemotherapy can be physically and emotionally exhausting. You mentioned concerns about work and home—can you tell me a bit more about what’s been difficult?
[PATIENT]: I’m a single mum, and I’ve had to take time off work. I’m worried about bills and keeping things stable for my daughter.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: That’s completely understandable. We can explore options for financial support, community services, and counselling. I can also help connect you with support groups for women going through similar experiences. Would that be helpful?
[PATIENT]: Yes, I think so. I just don’t know where to start.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: That’s okay—I'll walk you through it. You’re not alone in this, and we’ll make sure you have the support you need.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll check back in shortly, Ms. Bennett, and coordinate with Priya and Dr. Wallace’s team. Please use the call bell if you need anything.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Pain is being managed with regular paracetamol and PRN oxycodone. Pain score was 5/10 on movement this morning. He’s currently on bed rest and has been reminded to use the call bell before mobilising. A falls incident report has been completed.

[PATIENT]: Just sore in the hip, but no dizziness.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s tolerating oral intake and has no nausea. No signs of infection. Pre-op bloods and ECG have been completed. Consent for surgery is signed and documented. Physio will review post-op.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll follow up with the surgical team and ensure falls precautions are in place. Is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thanks.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Please use the call bell if you need anything. I’ll leave you in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back shortly to check your observations and review your chart, Mr. Jackson.

Hi, I’m heading off for my break now. Can I hand over Mrs. Margaret Ellis in bed 3 to you?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Sure, go ahead.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s 87, came in from Rosewood Nursing Home after a fall with head strike. There’s a small occipital hematoma, no loss of consciousness reported, but she’s been drowsy and mildly confused. Vitals are stable. GCS is 14.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Any advanced care planning?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she has a DNR order from the nursing home. Family is aware and on their way in—we’re waiting for them before making any escalation decisions.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any communication needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she’s deaf. No hearing aids with her today. She responds best to written notes and gestures. I’ve left a whiteboard and marker at the bedside.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Anything else I should know?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes, she’s just been found incontinent of urine. She needs to be cleaned up—I’ve gathered the continence supplies but haven’t had a chance to assist her yet. She’s calm and cooperative.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: No worries, I’ll take care of that now.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Perfect. Let me know if anything changes. I’ll be back in 30 minutes.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over bed 3, Mr. David Lee, 79 years old. He had a permanent pacemaker inserted this morning for complete heart block. Post-procedure, he developed a right-sided pneumothorax—a chest drain was inserted about an hour ago.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay—how is he now?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s more short of breath and becoming increasingly agitated. His oxygen requirement has gone up—now on 4 L via nasal prongs to maintain sats around 92%. BP is 98/60, HR is 62 (paced), RR 26, Temp 37.2. I’ve escalated to the medical registrar—awaiting review.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: How’s the drain functioning?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Swinging but minimal drainage so far. No signs of tension, but I’m concerned about his increased work of breathing and agitation. ECG shows paced rhythm, no acute changes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any other issues?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes—he’s acutely incontinent of urine and hasn’t voided since the procedure. Abdomen is mildly distended. I’ve requested an IDC insertion—awaiting medical clearance due to the recent pacing procedure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: IV access?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: One 18G in the left forearm—patent. He’s on maintenance fluids and has had IV paracetamol for discomfort. No antibiotics charted yet. NKDA.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any support needs?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: English is his first language. He’s usually independent but is now confused and distressed. Family has been notified and are on their way in.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll keep monitoring his respiratory status and follow up on the IDC and medical review.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. Please escalate if his condition worsens—especially if his sats drop further or he becomes more confused. All documentation is up to date, including drain chart, fluid balance, and neuro obs.

example.text:
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mr. Robert Hughes, 72 years old, currently admitted under a Treatment Authority. Diagnosis is late-onset schizophrenia, admitted with persecutory delusions.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s his presentation today?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He remains suspicious and is refusing meals, stating that his food is poisoned. He has refused his morning risperidone 0.5 mg and is declining all blood tests. He’s also refusing routine obs.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any signs of delirium?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes — 4AT score is 6. He appears intermittently disoriented and his mental state is fluctuating. Doctors have requested delirium care strategies — regular reorientation, low-stimulus environment, clear explanations. Food and fluid charts commenced.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: What’s his legal and social situation?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s under guardianship through the Office of the Public Guardian. No local family or supports.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: And the current risk and plan?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s refusing oral meds, so the team is considering alternative routes if refusal persists. Needs close supervision for nutrition, hydration, and risk of further deterioration. Maintain reorientation and escalate if agitation or aggression increases.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll continue with the delirium care approach and monitor intake and risk.

example.text:
[Hospital Nurse]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Emily Carter, a 38-year-old patient who was admitted three days ago and has now been newly diagnosed with bipolar disorder following a manic episode. She’s being discharged today and will require follow-up in the community.
[Community Nurse]: Thanks. Can you tell me a bit about her presentation?
[Hospital Nurse]: She was admitted after displaying elevated mood, pressured speech, and impulsive behaviour. No psychotic features noted. She’s now stabilised on medication and insight is improving. She’s aware of her diagnosis and has been engaging well with the mental health team.
[Community Nurse]: What’s her current medication regimen?
[Hospital Nurse]: She’s been started on: Lithium carbonate 400 mg BD – levels to be monitored, Quetiapine 300 mg nocte, PRN lorazepam 1 mg for agitation – not required in the last 48 hours there are No known drug allergies.
[Community Nurse]: Any physical health concerns?
[Hospital Nurse]: Vitals are stable. She’s independent with ADLs. No pressure areas noted. She’s been eating and drinking well, and her fluid balance is normal. Bowels have been regular.
[Community Nurse]: What’s her home situation?
[Hospital Nurse]: She lives with her husband and three children aged 4, 7, and 12, plus a dog. Her husband has been very supportive and is aware of the diagnosis. He’s keen to be involved in her care and has asked for education around mood monitoring and medication.
[Community Nurse]: Any follow-up arranged?
[Hospital Nurse]: Yes, she’s been referred to the community mental health team for ongoing support, including mood tracking, medication adherence, and psychoeducation. She’ll also need a home visit within 48 hours to assess safety and support needs.
[Community Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll follow up with the family and ensure she’s linked in with the right services.
[Hospital Nurse]: Great. Let me know if you need anything further from the inpatient team.

example.text:
[NURSE]: Hi Dr. Ahmed, I need you to urgently review Mr. Leonard Price in bed 10. He’s a 76-year-old patient with a history of congestive heart failure and COPD. He’s deteriorated over the last few hours with worsening shortness of breath and low oxygen saturations.
[DOCTOR]:
What’s happening currently?
[NURSE]: He’s tachypnoeic and using accessory muscles. His SpO? is 86% on 6 L via Hudson mask. He’s visibly distressed and unable to speak in full sentences. Auscultation reveals coarse crackles bilaterally. He’s likely fluid overloaded—his legs are oedematous, and his fluid balance is +1800 mL over the last 48 hours.
[DOCTOR]: What are his latest observations?
[NURSE]: BP: 158/92, HR: 112 bpm, RR: 32, Temp: 37.1°C, SpO?: 86% on 6 L O?, he’s  Alert but anxious his Q-ADDS score: 8 (SpO? + RR + HR + respiratory distress)
[DOCTOR]: Any current respiratory support?
[NURSE]: Not yet, but I believe he needs to be started on BiPAP. I’ve prepped the machine and mask. He’s not tolerating high-flow oxygen and is tiring.
[DOCTOR]: IV access?
[NURSE]: Yes, he has a 22G cannula in his right forearm, patent. No current IV fluids running. He’s on a fluid restriction chart.
[DOCTOR]: Medications?
[NURSE]:
He’s charted for: Frusemide 40 mg IV BD – last dose was this morning, Spiriva inhaler daily, PRN salbutamol neb – given 1 hour ago, Paracetamol 1g QID PRN. He has No known allergies.
[DOCTOR]: Thanks. We’ll start BiPAP immediately and arrange for transfer to HDU or the respiratory unit. Please continue monitoring and notify me of any changes.
[NURSE]: Will do. I’ll document the escalation and prep for transfer.

example.text:
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Hi there, I’m bringing in Mr. Jason Taylor, 34 years old. He’s been picked up from home following a welfare check requested by his GP. He’s known to have schizophrenia and is currently experiencing an acute psychotic episode.
[ED NURSE]: What’s been happening?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: He’s been verbally aggressive, paranoid, and disorganised in speech. He believes people are trying to harm him and has been refusing food and medication for the past few days. No physical aggression during transport, but he’s restless and pacing.
[ED NURSE]: Any injuries or medical concerns?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: No injuries. Vitals are within acceptable range: BP: 118/76 , HR: 92, RR: 20, Temp: 36.9°C, SpO?: 97% on room air.
[ED NURSE]: Any known medications or allergies?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: He’s prescribed olanzapine but I don't think he’s been taking it. He has a documented allergy to penicillin—rash and swelling reported previously.
[ED NURSE]: Any substance use?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Yes, he’s a regular cannabis user for anxiety and sleep, but he’s currently withdrawing—reports irritability and insomnia. GP flagged this as contributing to his current state. A Drug and Alcohol Team review is recommended.
[ED NURSE]: Is he medically cleared?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: He’s stable but needs a mental health assessment. No IV access yet—may need a cannula inserted if sedation or fluids are required. He’s not cooperative with physical exams. He is also under the mental health act.
[ED NURSE]: Thanks. We’ll get him triaged and notify the Mental Health Liaison Team. If needed, we’ll escalate for admission to the Mental Health Unit.
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Perfect. He’s currently in the waiting area with security nearby. Let me know if you need anything else.

[Nursing Home Nurse]: Any ongoing care needs?

Continue monitoring. He’s Mobilising with assistance. Physiotherapy has recommended gentle walking with a frame. His Q-ADDS score: Currently 2 (mild fatigue and recent infection). [Nursing Home Nurse]: Any medications or allergies?
[Hospital Nurse]: He’s on: Amoxicillin 500 mg TDS (3 days remaining), Paracetamol 1g QID PRN, Atorvastatin 20 mg nocte, he has No known drug allergies.
[Nursing Home Nurse]: Thanks. I’ll continue monitoring and update the GP if needed.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good morning, Mr. Smith. I’m Alex, I'm one of the nurses from the City Hospital where you're being transferred to. I’ll get handover from my colleague now, is that okay?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: This is bed 12, John Smith, 78 years old, under Dr. Patel.
He was admitted two days ago following a fall at home, resulting in a displaced fracture of the left femur. He’s being transferred for surgical fixation.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He has a history of Type 2 Diabetes and mild dementia. He’s usually oriented to person and place but can become confused in unfamiliar environments. Observations have been stable, and pain is managed with regular paracetamol.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:
Hi Mr. Smith, can you tell us your full name to confirm your ID?
[PATIENT]: John Smith.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: And your date of birth?.
[PATIENT]: first of June 1948 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I'll check you ID number on your wristband, it's 479023, which is correct. Are you having any discomfort right now?
[PATIENT]: Just a bit of pain in my leg, but it’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No interventions overnight. Vital signs remained within normal limits: BP: 132/78, HR:88, RR:18, Temp: 36.8. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Any allergies we should know about? I’ll double-check your chart as well.
[PATIENT]: Please check the chart.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Bloods from yesterday show: Hb:125, CRP:12, HbA1c:7.4 from last month. 
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s currently NBM for surgery. IV fluids are running at maintenance rate.
No anticoagulants. Pressure area care in place. Nil weight-bearing.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: So, the plan is to continue monitoring and prepare for surgical fixation. There are no outstanding tasks at this stage.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Everything is up to date.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr. Smith, is there anything you need before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:
Okay, I’ll be back shortly to check on you again.

example.text:
[ED_NURSE]:
Hi, thanks for coming. I’m handing over Mr. Leo Martinez, 56 years old, admitted through ED earlier today with chest pain and a history of Type 2 diabetes. He also consumed a large amount of alcohol last night and presented confused and groggy.
[WARD_NURSE]: What’s his current status?
[ED_NURSE]: He’s still a bit drowsy, but responsive. Chest pain has eased slightly with initial treatment. Vitals are stable BP: 108/72, HR: 96 bpm, RR: 20, SpO?: 95% on room air, Temp: 36.7°C, BGL: 14.2 mmol/L on arrival, now 11.6 mmol/L
[DOCTOR]: We’re admitting him for cardiac monitoring and further investigation. ECG showed non-specific changes, and we’re awaiting troponin results. He’s also at risk of alcohol withdrawal, so we’ve started a CIWA protocol and charted thiamine and diazepam PRN.
[WARD_NURSE]: Any IV access?
[ED_NURSE]: Yes, he has a 20G cannula in the left forearm, patent and flushed. Fluids are running at maintenance rate.
[WARD_NURSE]: Any allergies or regular meds?
[ED_NURSE]: No known drug allergies. Regular meds include, Metformin 500 mg BD, Atorvastatin 20 mg nocte, PRN insulin sliding scale (not charted today due to alcohol intake)
[DOCTOR]: We’ll need to involve the Drug and Alcohol Team tomorrow for support. He’s also been referred to Cardiology for review.
[WARD_NURSE]: Is he safe to mobilise?
[ED_NURSE]:
Not really sure we haven't tried to get him up.
[PATIENT]: Where am I now?
[WARD_NURSE]: Hi Mr. Martinez, you’re being moved to the ward now so we can keep a close eye on your heart and help you feel better. I’ll be looking after you.
[PATIENT]: Okay… my chest still feels tight.
[DOCTOR]: We’ll keep monitoring that. Let us know if it gets worse.
[WARD_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll get him settled and continue obs and withdrawal monitoring.
[ED_NURSE]: Perfect. All documentation is up to date. Let me know if you need anything

[ED NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Maria Santos, 58 years old, coming up to the ward with cellulitis on her left lower leg. She’s been started on IV antibiotics and is stable for transfer.
[WARD NURSE]: Thanks. What’s her current status?
[ED NURSE]: Vitals are stable — temp 37.6°C, HR 84, BP 122/78, RR 18, SpO? 98% on room air. The affected leg is red, warm, and swollen from mid-calf to ankle. No signs of abscess or necrosis.
[WARD NURSE]: Okay. What’s the antibiotic plan?
[ED NURSE]: She’s on IV cefazolin, 1g every 8 hours. First dose was given in ED about an hour ago. Next dose is due at 10 PM. No known drug allergies.
[WARD NURSE]: Got it. Any IV access?
[ED NURSE]: Yes, 20G cannula in the right forearm — site is clean, dry, and patent. Charted for daily review. She’s also had IV fluids earlier, but now tolerating oral intake.
[WARD NURSE]: Any pain management?
[ED NURSE]: She’s had paracetamol 1g orally — pain is currently 4/10. PRN analgesia is charted.
[WARD NURSE]: Any behavioural or cognitive concerns?
[ED NURSE]: No concerns. She’s alert, oriented, and understands the treatment plan. Mobilising with assistance due to leg discomfort.
[WARD NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll check the IV site and meds when she arrives. Let me know if anything changes before transfer.

[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Hi there, I’m bringing in Mrs. Margaret Ellis, 87 years old, from Rosewood Nursing Home. She had a fall earlier this morning—staff found her on the floor next to her bed. She’s hit her head, and there’s a small occipital hematoma. No loss of consciousness reported, but she’s been drowsy and confused since.
[ED NURSE]: Thanks. Any known medical history?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Yes, she has: Hypertension, Osteoarthritis, Early-stage dementia and a Profound hearing loss – she’s deaf and communicates via written notes and gestures. No hearing aids in place today.
[ED NURSE]: Any medications or allergies?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: She’s on amlodipine and paracetamol regularly. No known drug allergies.
[ED NURSE]: What’s her current condition?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]:
Vitals on arrival: BP: 102/64, HR: 88, RR: 18, Temp: 36.7°C, SpO?: 97% on room air
She’s responsive but confused. No vomiting. GCS is 14.
[ED NURSE]: Any advanced care directives?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Yes, nursing home staff provided documentation indicating a Do Not Resuscitate (DNR) order. There’s also a note that family must be involved in any escalation decisions. Her daughter and son are on their way to the hospital now.
[ED NURSE]: Thanks. Any IV access?
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: No IV inserted yet. She may need one for imaging or fluids depending on your assessment.
[ED NURSE]:  We’ll get her triaged and notify the medical team. I’ll also make sure we have written communication tools available for her.
[AMBULANCE OFFICER]: Perfect. She’s currently calm but may need reassurance once she’s in the bay.

For now, just rest and keep the arm supported. After surgery, we’ll start gentle exercises and discuss strategies for managing daily tasks one-handed.
[PATIENT]: Okay, I’m worried about how I’ll manage with the kids.
[PHYSIOTHERAPIST]: That’s understandable. We’ll work closely with the social worker and nursing team to make sure you have the right support in place.

[PATIENT]: It’s just me and the kids. My mum lives interstate and I don’t have anyone nearby.
[SOCIAL WORKER]: Thanks for sharing. I’ll look into short-term home care options and community support services. We can also explore childcare assistance while you recover. I’ll keep you updated and help with any paperwork.
[NURSE AMY]: I’ll continue monitoring your pain and neurovascular status, and coordinate with the surgical team. Let me know if you need anything, Jessica.
[PATIENT]: Thank you. I really appreciate it.

[NIGHT_NURSE]: Morning. Handing over Mrs. Evelyn Taylor, 81 years old, in bed 7. Evelyn, this is Nurse Mia, who’ll be looking after you today.
[MORNING_NURSE]: Hi Evelyn, I’ll be your nurse this morning. How are you feeling?
[PATIENT]: I feel a bit strange. My right arm feels heavy, and I’m having trouble speaking clearly.
[NIGHT_NURSE]: That’s actually new. She was drowsy overnight, but I thought it was just fatigue. I didn’t notice any clear deficits during the night, but she’s now showing slurred speech and right-sided weakness. I’ve just done a quick neuro check—there’s a facial droop and reduced grip on the right.
[MORNING_NURSE]: That sounds like a possible stroke. Has the doctor been notified?
[NIGHT_NURSE]: Not yet—I picked it up just before handover. I was about to escalate. She’s on Q-ADDS, scoring 6 now—due to new neuro changes and slightly elevated BP (162/94). HR 84, RR 18, SpO? 97% on room air, Temp 36.6.
[MORNING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll call the medical registrar immediately and start hourly neuro obs.
[DOCTOR]: (enters) I’ve just been informed. Evelyn, I’m Dr. Singh. We’re concerned you may have had a stroke overnight, and we’re going to do some urgent tests, including a CT scan.
[PATIENT]: Oh… I didn’t realise. I just thought I was tired.
[DOCTOR]: You did the right thing by speaking up. We’ll take care of you.
[MORNING_NURSE]: I’ll stay with her and start the neuro obs now. Is she nil by mouth?
[DOCTOR]: Yes, keep her NPO until we assess her swallow. I’ll organise an urgent stroke team review.
[NIGHT_NURSE]: She’s on a fluid balance chart, and her oral intake was minimal overnight. No IV fluids running yet. She’s on regular antihypertensives and aspirin. No known allergies.
[MORNING_NURSE]: Got it. I’ll update the family once we have a clearer picture.
[NIGHT_NURSE]: Thanks. All documentation is up to date—Q-ADDS, med chart, and fluid balance.

[WARD NURSE]: Hi, I’m handing over Mrs. Evelyn Grant, 87 years old, being transferred to the transit lounge to await transport back to her nursing home. Evelyn, this is Nurse Tom, who’ll be looking after you until your transport arrives.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Hi Evelyn, lovely to meet you. We’ll make sure you’re comfortable while you wait.
[WARD NURSE]: Evelyn was admitted five days ago with aspiration pneumonia. She’s responded well to IV antibiotics and supportive care. She’s now afebrile, respiratory rate is 18, SpO? 96% on room air, and she’s mobilising short distances with assistance.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Great. Any swallowing concerns?
[WARD NURSE]: Yes, she has known dysphagia—thickened fluids and minced moist diet. She’s been reviewed by speech pathology and is safe to resume her usual nursing home diet plan. No signs of aspiration since admission.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Okay. Any medications due?
[WARD NURSE]: No meds due during transit. She’s had her morning meds—oral antibiotics completed yesterday. No allergies. She has a 22G IV in the left hand, but it can be removed before discharge.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Any behavioural concerns?
[WARD NURSE]: No. She’s pleasant, a bit confused at times but reorients easily. Nursing home staff are aware and familiar with her baseline.
[TRANSIT LOUNGE NURSE]: Got it. Is transport booked?
[WARD NURSE]: Yes, booked for 11:30 AM. All discharge paperwork is complete, including medication summary and nursing home handover form. Please let the team know if there’s any delay or change in her condition.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Eric. This is Sam, the day nurse taking over from me.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi, Eric. We’ll do your handover together at the bedside.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Bed eight is Eric Wong, he is 69 years old, under Dr Johnson.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s come in for management of high cholesterol. The Plan is for daily bloods and a carotid Doppler ultrasound tomorrow.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s also booked for an arterial/vascular study so they can start his medication.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Do we have times yet?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No they are not confirmed yet. He’s quite anxious about the tests.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Could we get the medical team to come and explain the procedure to him today?
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Absolutely—I’ll page Dr Johnson’s team to talk you through everything, Eric.
[PATIENT]: Thanks, I’m just a bit worried about what it involves.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Totally understandable. We’ll make sure someone explains it clearly and answers your questions before anything happens.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s on a general diet, ambulant, and self-caring.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: History of high blood pressure; otherwise observations have been stable. The team is aware.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll keep monitoring your BP and we’ll get today’s bloods done as ordered.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Eric, is there anything you need right now?
[PATIENT]: No, I’m okay. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: All right, I’ll follow up with the doctors and come back with an update.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me. Thanks, Eric.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Frank. I’m the day nurse coming on now my name is Henry. I’ll get a quick handover from Arthur at the bedside if that’s okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Hi. This is bed 5, Frank Morgan Montgomery. Frank, this is the incoming nurse who’ll be looking after you today.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Frank—could you tell me your full name and date of birth.
[PATIENT]: Frank Morgan Montgomery, 25 October 1947.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Frank is 78 years old and under Dr. Sanchez. He came in with shortness of breath and tiredness post‑op. He has a history of CABG eight years ago. We’ve noted a decreasing level of consciousness, so neuro observations are being done QID. He was tachy this morning—post‑op—and he’s on oxygen at 3 liters via nasal prongs. His oxygen saturations are all good now. He’s here for further monitoring.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  Has there been any changes to his LOC since earlier?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He's a little drowsy compared to baseline but rousable; no acute deterioration since last my last round.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll keep a close eye and escalate if there’s any decline. Frank, how’s your breathing feeling right now?
[PATIENT]: Better than before, just a bit tired.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: All right. We’ll continue monitoring your heart rate, breathing, and level of alertness. If you feel more short of breath or more drowsy, please let us know.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Anything else outstanding—bloods, scans, or new orders?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: No new orders noted; just ongoing monitoring.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll check your vitals shortly, Frank, and make sure you’re comfortable. Do you need anything before we finish handover?
[PATIENT]: No, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: All right, Frank. I’m heading off now. You’re in good hands.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll be back in a moment to recheck your observations.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Alistair, I’m the incoming nurse for the day, my name is Dan. We’ll do a quick bedside handover with you, if that’s okay.
[PATIENT]: Sure.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Could you confirm your full name, please?

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. And any allergies?

[INCOMING_NURSE]: All right. If anything changes—more swelling, wheeze, or trouble breathing—please press the call bell straight away.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Great. I’ll hand over to you now.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. I’ll be back shortly to recheck you, Alistair.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Good Morning, Mr Hunt. I’m taking over your care now. We’ll just do a quick bedside handover with my colleague, okay?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks. This is Abraham Hunt, 83 years old, under Dr Jamie.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Mr Hunt, could you confirm your name for me?
[PATIENT]: Abraham Hunt.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you. Any medication allergies that you know of? and when was the cannula inserted?
[PATIENT]: No, not that I know of, it was put in yesterday in ED.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He presented with chest pain, but it’s more likely not cardiac-related. He does have a history of a heart attack five years ago.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Dave, I’m Jess, I’ll be looking after you today. I’m just getting handover from Sam who’s finishing the night shift. Is it okay if we talk through things at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Yeah… okay.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Thanks, Dave. So, this is Room 2, Bed 3: Dave McKenzie, 72 years old. He’s a new admission, arrived a few hours ago under Dr George De Silva with a background of dementia.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Dave, can you tell me your name?
[PATIENT]: Dave… McKenzie.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thank you, Dave. I’ll just check your ID band… all good.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The Presenting issue is increasing confusion. They’re querying a UTI. He’s still for bloods and a urine MCS—I haven’t had a chance to do those yet. They’ve started him on oral antibiotics.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, so I need to do bloods and a urine MCS. I’ll get onto those this morning.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His medical history includes CCF, hypertension, type 2 diabetes on oral hypoglycemics, and he has chronic back pain, in addition to the dementia.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s resting in bed at the moment. I haven’t seen him mobilise yet, so I’d suggest a physio referral. He’s also been refusing his meals, so a dietitian referral would be helpful.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll place referrals to physio and dietetics and reassess his intake.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: His observations have been stable since arrival. No other acute concerns noted.I have been watching him to make sure he doesn't go wandering off the ward.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay. Any family updates?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: He’s for nursing home placement; his wife has been informed about the admission.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Dave, we’re going to take some blood tests and a urine sample a bit later, and I’ll check in about food and how you’re feeling. Is there any pain right now?
[PATIENT]: My back’s okay… just tired.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: We’ll keep you comfortable.

[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me don't forget the bloods and urine sample, the antibiotics are due now. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Perfect. I’ll get started on those now. Dave, press your call bell if you need anything.
[PATIENT]: Okay.

[INCOMING_NURSE]: Hi Cecilia, I’m Sam, I’ll be looking after you today. Is it okay if we do your handover at the bedside?
[PATIENT]: Yes, that’s fine.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: We’re in Bed 1, This is Cecilia Ramos, 38, under Dr Willow. Admitted with a renal obstruction; Her full history is in the notes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: I’ll just check your ID band, Cecilia… great, thank you.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She had a CT scan last week. She has been charted pain medication. 
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Cecilia, how’s your pain right now?
[PATIENT]: It’s still there, but manageable.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Okay, I’ll keep an eye on your timing and make sure you’re comfortable.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: The Plan is to discharge at the end of this week and Follow‑up with Dr Willow one week post discharge and book a renal outpatients appointment for two weeks after discharge. The discharge summary is at the front of the notes.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  Are we just waiting on medications to go home?
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: Yes we are waiting for the discharge meds from pharmacy.
[INCOMING_NURSE]:  I’ll chase those up.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: She’s quite anxious. Family is in attendance at the moment.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Cecilia, we’ll keep you updated about timing and the medications so you’re not left wondering.
[PATIENT]: I appreciate that. I’ve been a bit worried.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Of course. I’ll check in regularly, and if anything changes with your pain or you have questions, press the call bell.
[OUTGOING_NURSE]: That’s everything from me. See you tomorrow.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Thanks. Anything else you’d like us to know or anything you need right now, Cecilia?
[PATIENT]: No, that’s all. Thank you.
[INCOMING_NURSE]: Great—I’ll follow up pharmacy and be back shortly.
